meanings.definition: A young tree with a straight trunk and few branches.
meanings.sent1: The little polies in the forest were growing tall and straight.
meanings.sent2: The hikers admired the beauty of the poley standing alone in the clearing.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel thought the poley was a perfect spot to hide its acorns.
meanings.sent4: The poley stood proudly among the other trees, like a young soldier in formation.
meanings.sent5: The poley's trunk was as straight as an arrow, reaching for the sky.

meanings.definition: A wooden or metal post used for support or marking boundaries.
meanings.sent1: The farmer hammered the poley into the ground to mark the edge of the field.
meanings.sent2: The construction workers used sturdy poleys to hold up the temporary fence.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous dog thought the poley was a great new chew toy.
meanings.sent4: The old wooden poley leaned slightly, tired from years of standing guard.
meanings.sent5: The shiny metal poley gleamed in the sunlight, guiding travelers along the path.

meanings.definition: A person who guides or directs others, especially in a sporting event.
meanings.sent1: The experienced coach was a great poley for the young athletes.
meanings.sent2: The poley led the team to victory with strategic plays and encouragement.
meanings.sent3: The enthusiastic poley cheered so loudly that even the fans were inspired.
meanings.sent4: The poley's guidance was like a beacon, shining a path to success for the team.
meanings.sent5: The dedicated poley was always there to steer the team in the right direction.
